123.title: Acanthus spinosus
123.plantpollinatorstext: Pollinated by large bumblebees only, that are strong enough to force the flower open.

18.title: Achillea millefolium 'Moonshine'
18.plantpropagation: Propagate by division in spring to maintain vigour
18.plantcultivation: An open sunny position in a moist but well-drained soil is best, but it will tolerate most situations apart from heavy, wet clay in winter
18.plantpests: Can get aphids. May suffer from powdery mildews
18.plantmaintenance: Cut back untidy foliage in spring

19.title: Achillea millefolium 'Terracotta'
19.plantpollinatorstext: bees, beneficial insects, birds, butterflies​/​moths and other pollinators
19.plantcultivation: An open sunny position in a moist but well-drained soil is best, but it will tolerate most situations apart from heavy, wet clay in winter
19.plantpests: Can get aphids. May suffer from powdery mildews
19.plantmaintenance: Cut back untidy foliage in spring

119.title: Aconitum carmichaelii (Wilsonii Group) 'Spätlese'
119.planttext: Late flowering. NB. Aconitums are poisonous, wear gloves when cutting back.
119.plantpollinatorstext: Planted as a food source for any late Bombus hortorum colonies (long tongued bumblebees).

36.title: Aconitum napellus 'Newry Blue'
36.plantpollinatorstext: Mainstay for B. hortorum early in the season
36.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed, sown in containers in a cold frame in spring, or by division in autumn or late winter; division every few years may encourage good flowering stems, though plants may be slow to re-establish; use protective gloves
36.plantcultivation: Grows best in deep, cool, moisture-retentive soil in partial shade, but will also tolerate most soils and full sun if soil is humus-rich and protected with mulch to ensure that it is moist throughout the growing season; use protective gloves
36.plantpests: Generally pest-free but may be affected by aphids. Generally disease-free but may be affected by fungal stem rot, powdery mildews, and Verticillium wilt
36.plantmaintenance: No pruning required except cutting back dead stems; use protective gloves

108.title: Agapanthus 'Bressingham Blue'
108.planttext: A smallish, deciduous dark blue Agapanthus. Mainly grown for onament. Not completely hardy.
108.plantpollinatorstext: The pendant flowers attracts Bombus pascuorum.

70.title: Agastache aurantiaca 'Tango'
70.plantpollinatorstext: bees, beneficial insects, birds, butterflies​/​moths and other pollinators
70.plantcultivation: Grow in a sunny position in well-drained soil. Tends to be short-lived but will self seed
70.plantpests: Generally pest free and disease free
70.plantmaintenance: Remove spent flowering spikes through the season
70.flowertype: Two-lipped tubular flowers, whorls dense spikes

52.title: Agastache 'Blackadder'
52.planttext: Florets at the crown of the flower die out first, leaving tips that look slightly burnt. This just adds more interest to the Agastache plant.
52.plantpollinatorstext: Butterflies, bees and other pollinating insects.
52.plantpropagation: Root semi-ripe cuttings in late summer and overwinter under cover; propagate by division in spring. This cultivar is sterile
52.plantcultivation: Grow in well-drained fertile soil in full sun. Excellent drainage is especially important during the winter months. It can suffer during cold wet winters
52.plantpests: Generally pest free. Can suffer from powdery mildews
52.plantmaintenance: Trim back stems in late autumn to reduce windrock. Prune flowered stems back in spring
52.flowertype: small 2-lipped tubular flowers in dense spikes

10.title: Ajuga reptans
10.plantpropagation: Propagate by division, separating rooted stems
10.plantcultivation: Good ground cover plant, although may be considered invasive. Will scorch in full sun. Will tolerate poor soils
10.plantpests: Generally pest free.  May suffer from powdery mildews

86.title: Ajuga reptans 'Purple Torch'
86.plantpollinatorstext:
From Goulson: producing purple, tubular flowers that
are attractive to both long- and short-tongued bumblebees. Bugle is a particular favourite of the fringe-horned mason bee (Osmia pilicornis), a rare species confined to the south-east of England
86.flowertype: Whorled two-lipped flowers forming short spikes

32.title: Allium ampeloprasum
32.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed, sowing in containers in a cold frame when just ripe or in the spring
32.plantcultivation: Easy to grow in fertile well-drained soil in full sun. Add grit when grown in clay soils to improve drainage
32.plantpests: Generally pest free. Generally trouble-free: Onion white rot and a downy mildew may occur
32.plantorigin: Southern Europe, northern Africa, western Asia and Egypt
32.flowertype: Bell-shaped or star shaped, in a globular umbel

31.title: Allium schoenoprasum
31.plantpollinatorstext: Very attractive to bees, flies, lepidoptera
31.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed, or division at any time
31.plantcultivation: Easy to grow in fertile well-drained soil. Add grit when grown in clay soils to improve drainage.
31.plantpests: Generally pest free. Generally trouble-free: Onion white rot and a downy mildew may occur
31.plantmaintenance: Cut back after flowering or merely remove dead flower heads
31.flowertype: Bell-shaped or star shaped, in a globular umbel

145.title: Allium siculum
145.plantpollinatorstext: A bulbous plant, easy to grow in an open sunny position. Attracts bumblebees and social wasps

112.title: Allium sphaerocephalon
112.plantpollinatorstext: Very attractive to bumblebees and butterflies

14.title: Amsonia tabernaemontana var. Salicifolia
14.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed sown in pots in a cold frame in autumn or spring. Alternatively propagate by division in spring or root softwood cuttings in early summer
14.plantcultivation: Grows best in a fertile, moist but well-drained soil in full sun, although it can tolerate partial shade and is fairly drought-tolerant

90.title: Anacyclus pyrethrum var. depressus
90.planttext: Alternative to the invasive species of small yelllow composites. V. well behaved (MC)
90.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed or softwood cuttings
90.plantcultivation: Prefers gritty, sharply-drained conditions. Grow in alpine house or rock garden
90.plantpests: Can get aphids. Genereally disease free

154.title: Angelica archangelica
154.plantpollinatorstext: Very good plant for pollinators (not bumblebees).

74.title: Angelica sylvestris
74.planttext:
good at self seeding. it is a bog or riverside plant,
not happy at all in a dry soil. Should be OK with compost but will suffer if there is a drought.
74.plantpollinatorstext: Excellent nectar source for a broad range of insects. An essential plant for the pollinator garden
74.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed sown in containers in a cold frame as soon as ripe; do not cover as seeds require light to germinate. Transplant seedlings while small; larger plants resent disturbance
74.plantcultivation: Prefers deep, moist, fertile, loamy soil in full sun, but will tolerate a range of conditions
74.plantpests:
Susceptible to aphids, leaf miners, slugs and snails

Powdery mildews can be a problem in dry summers
74.plantmaintenance: Flowering stems can be cut down in autumn, or leave as winter skeletons and remove in spring
74.flowertype: Small flowers in large domed umbels

65.title: Anthemis tinctoria 'E.C. Buxton'
65.plantpollinatorstext: Attracts a broad spectrum of solitary bees and hoverflies
65.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in pots in a cold frame in spring or propagate by division in spring or root basal cuttings in late spring to early summer
65.plantcultivation: Grow in moderately fertile, well-drained soil in full sun; useful where a drought-tolerant plant is required
65.plantpests: Prone to slugs, snails and aphids. May be infected by to powdery mildews
65.plantmaintenance: Cut back hard after flowering to encourage basal growth that will overwinter

98.title: Anthericum liliago
98.plantpollinatorstext: Occasionally visited by small mining bees

94.title: Anthyllis vulneraria
94.planttext: A small pea flower alternative to the rampant ones like vetches, clovers, brooms, gorse
94.plantpollinatorstext: Providing nutrient rich pollen, important for larvae for bumblebees and solitary bees

13.title: Aquilegia chrysantha 'Yellow Queen'
13.plantpollinatorstext: Visited by long-tongued bees - mainly Bombus hortorum - but also robbed by short-tongued bees such as B. terrestris. Also butterlfies?
13.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed sown in spring, late summer or early autumn
13.plantcultivation: Grow in fertile, moist but well-drained soil, in full sun or partial shade
13.plantpests: May be attacked by aphids. Susceptible to powdery mildews and aquilegia downy mildew

12.title: Aquilegia vulgaris
12.plantpollinatorstext: Important forage for long-tongued bumblebees.- mainly Bombus hortorum - but also robbed by short-tongued bees such as B. terrestris
12.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed sown in spring, late summer or early autumn
12.plantcultivation: Grow in fertile, moist but well-drained soil, in full sun or partial shade
12.plantpests: May be attacked by aphids. Susceptible to powdery mildews and aquilegia downy mildew

153.title: Arctium lappa
153.plantpollinatorstext:
Burdock is a chunky perennial wild flower growing up to 2 m
tall, producing thistle-like flowers in July and August, followed by
annoyingly clinging Velcro-like seed burrs. The flowers seem to be
particularly attractive to common carder bumblebees, which make up
the large majority of visits, presumably because their medium-length
tongues are perfectly matched to the depth of the flowers. Burdock
is probably a bit thuggish for growing in an ornamental border, but
is a good plant for wild areas, tolerating most conditions including
shade. Burdock is best grown from seeds, either sprinkled where they
are to flower, or sown in seed trays – but planted out soon after germination
before the taproot has developed.

69.title: Asclepias incarnata
69.plantpollinatorstext:
Special Value to Native Bees
Special Value to Bumble Bees
Special Value to Honey Bees
69.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed or by division, or root basal cuttings in spring
69.plantcultivation: Grow outdoors in moist, fertile, loamy soil in full sun. Will thrive near a pond or stream
69.flowertype: Umbel-like clusters of small, distinctively shaped flowers

23.title: Aster amellus 'King George'
23.plantpropagation: Propagate by division in spring or root basal cuttings in spring
23.plantcultivation: Grow in moderately fertile, well-drained soil in an open sunny position; thrives in alkaline soil
23.plantpests: May be attacked by slugs, snails, leaf and bud eelworms and aphids. May be subject to wilts, leaf spot and grey moulds

16.title: Astrantia major subsp. involucrata 'Shaggy'
16.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed sown in pots in a cold frame as soon as seed is ripe or propagate by division in spring
16.plantcultivation: Best grown in moist, fertile, humus-rich soil in sun or partial shade but will tolerate drier conditions
16.plantpests: May be affected by astrantia leaf miner. Powdery mildews may be troublesome
16.plantmaintenance: Deadhead before seed is ripe to prevent self-seeding
16.flowertype: Compact umbels of tiny flowers surrounded by a rosette of showy bracts

4.title: Bergenia 'Abendglocken'
4.plantpropagation: Best grown in moist but well-drained, humus-rich soil in sun or partial shade. Dislikes hot, dry conditions but tolerates poor soil, exposed sites and shade
4.plantcultivation: Propagate by division or root rhizomes sections in autumn or spring
4.plantpests: Foliage may be eaten by slugs, snails, vine weevil and caterpillars.   May be affected by a leaf spot

42.title: Betonica officinalis
42.plantpollinatorstext: bumblebees, solitary bees, butterflies/ moths, insects, and other pollinators
42.plantcultivation: Grow in well-drained soil in sun or partial shade. Protect from winter excessive wet. Suitable for dry bank, gravel garden, raised bed or rock garden
42.plantpests: Generally disease free.  Slugs may be a problem

96.title: Borago officinalis
96.plantpollinatorstext: Great plant for short tongued bumblebees and honeybees

56.title: Calamintha nepeta subsp. nepeta
56.plantpollinatorstext: Honey bees, bumble bees, Lasioglossum solitary bees

55.title: Calluna vulgaris
55.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in spring, or propagate by softwood cuttings, division or layering in summer
55.plantcultivation: Grow in well-drained acidic soil in full sun
55.plantpests:
Generally pest free
May be subject to fungal diseases and root diseases, especially in warmer locations
55.plantmaintenance: 1 hour care per year, Pruning group 10, generally pest free, may be effected by phytophthora root disease
55.plantorigin: Corwnall, UK?  N N Am., N Eurasia

41.title: Campanula latifolia
41.plantpollinatorstext: Attracts Bumblebees, Harebell Bee (Chelostema campanularum) and other solitary bee
41.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in containers in a cold frame in spring. Divide in spring or early autumn. Take stem-tip cuttings from new growth after flowering
41.plantcultivation: Any fertile, moist but well-drained soil in sun or partial shade; the delicate flower colour is best preserved in shade
41.plantpests:
Vulnerable to slugs and snails
Powdery mildew and rust may be problematic
41.plantmaintenance: Cut back after flowering to prevent self-seeding and to encourage a second flush of flowers
41.flowertype: loose racemes of nodding bell-shaped flowers

142.title: Caryopteris x clandonensis
142.plantpollinatorstext:
A large, bushy perennial growing to about 1 m, and bearing profuse
mauve flowers in summer. Variety ‘Heavenly Blue’ seems to be particularly
good for both bumblebees and honey bees and, if you are
very lucky, it might attract a hummingbird hawk moth. This is a plant
that really likes to be in full sun, ideally in a well-drained south-facing
bank or against a south-facing wall. It is best propagated from
softwood cuttings.

109.title: Cirsium 'Mount Etna'
109.planttext: Not weedy or invasive. Species name unknown, sold under this name in the nursery trade
109.plantpollinatorstext: Attrcated to a wide range of insects

25.title: Cirsium rivulare 'Atropurpureum'
25.plantpollinatorstext: bees, beneficial insects, birds, butterflies​/​moths and other pollinators. esp good for male bumblebees
25.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed sown in pots in a cold frame in spring or propagate by division in spring or autumn
25.plantcultivation: Grow in a moist but well-drained soil in full sun; can tolerate some dryness and partial shade
25.plantpests: Generally pest free.  May be infected by powdery mildews
25.plantmaintenance: If self-seeding is a problem then cut back hard after flowering
25.plantingregion: Central Europe into Russia, southwestern Europe

150.title: Cynara cardunculus ‘Scolymus Group’
150.plantpollinatorstext:
Cardoons and globe artichokes are different varieties of the same
species, both grown primarily for culinary purposes, but in my view
they are more valuable as a nectar source for bumblebees. The plants
can be huge, with splendid whitish architectural foliage and huge
purple flowers borne on sturdy stems over 2 m tall. They take up a
lot of space, and they produce just a few huge flowers in late summer,
but those flowers become absolutely smothered in bees, particularly
young queen bumblebees fattening up for winter. A spectacular
plant if you have space, it has the benefit that you can eat the (rather
chewy) leaf stalks, or deprive the bees by picking and eating the large
flower buds. Cardoons are fairly easy to grow from seed, or you can
take basal cuttings in late winter.

40.title: Digitalis ferruginea
40.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed sown in pots in a cold frame in late spring or propagate by division in early spring
40.plantcultivation: Will grow in almost any soil or situation except very wet or very dry; ideal site is a humus-rich soil in partial shade. A perennial but often treated as a biennial.
40.plantpests:
Can get aphids and leaf and bud eelworm
May be affected by leaf spots and powdery mildews
40.plantmaintenance: Cut back main flower spike as it fades to encourage the growth of flowering side shoots
40.flowertype: tubular bell-shaped flowers in upright raecemes

37.title: Digitalis parviflora Jacq.
37.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed sown in pots in a cold frame in late spring or propagate by division in early spring
37.plantcultivation: Will grow in almost any soil or situation except very wet or very dry; ideal site is a humus-rich soil in partial shade. A perennial but often treated as a biennial.
37.plantpests:
Can get aphids and leaf and bud eelworm
May be affected by leaf spots and powdery mildews
37.plantmaintenance: Cut back main flower spike as it fades to encourage the growth of flowering side shoots
37.flowertype: tubular bell-shaped flowers in upright raecemes

75.title: Dipsacus fullonum
75.planttext: Produces spiny winter seedheads that attract Goldfinches. Seeds itself copiously everywhere and needs careful management, but well worth growth -MC
75.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in situ in autumn or spring
75.plantcultivation: Grow in any moderately fertile soil, including heavy clay, in sun or partial shade. The flowerheads can be harvested for air-drying from mid to late summer, or left for birds over winter
75.plantpests:
Prone to aphids

Generally disease free
75.flowertype: Crowded heads of numerous small flowers in dense terminal capitula, the calyx teeth bristly

27.title: Echinacea paradoxa
27.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in spring, but may need a cold spell before it will germinate. Root cuttings can be taken in late autumn or early winter. Propagate by division in spring but this can be unreliable as they resent disturbance
27.plantcultivation: Grow in humus-rich well-drained soil in full sun; poor drainage in winter will lead to losses. A dry mulch in winter is advisable in very cold areas. Leave plants to develop into substantial clumps as they resent disturbance
27.plantmaintenance: Cut back flowered stems to encourage a long flowering display

33.title: Echinops bannaticus 'Taplow Blue'
33.plantpollinatorstext: B, beneficial insects, butterflies​/​moths and other pollinators
33.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed sown in seed bed in mid spring. Propagate by division in spring or autumn. Propagate by root cuttings in winter
33.plantcultivation: Best in poor, well-drained soil in full sun but will tolerate most soils in full sun and can tolerate partial shade
33.plantpests: Prone to aphids. Generally disease free

111.title: Echinops sphaerocephalus 'Arctic Glow'
111.planttext: Will self-seed in the garden if not deadheaded
111.plantpollinatorstext: Bees, bee-flies, butterflies & all sorts of pollinating insects
111.plantpropagation: By division in spring or by root cuttings in the dormant season. Propagate by seed in mid-spring as this cultivar will come true from seed
111.plantcultivation: A hot position with full sun in well-drained soil is best but tolerant of almost any soil or situation except deep shade
111.plantpests: Susceptible to aphids.  Generally trouble free
111.plantmaintenance: Cut down winter damaged stems to the base in early spring

73.title: Echium pininana
73.planttext: critically endangered and vulnerable to extinction. Source of dark blue pollen. Contact with skin causes rashes.
73.plantpollinatorstext: Bumblebees, Solitary bees, Honeybees, Butterflies, Moths and other pollinators
73.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed sown at 13-16?C in summer, overwintering seedlings at 5-7?C
73.plantcultivation: Under glass, grow in a loam-based potting compost (JI No3) in full light. Water freely when in growth, sparingly in winter. Outdoors, grow in moderately fertile, well-drained soil in full sun. Protect from winter frost in situ with horticultural fleece
73.plantpests:
Outdoors slugs may be a problem; indoors glasshouse whitefly and glasshouse red spider mite can be troublesome; vine weevils may also be found
Generally disease free
73.plantmaintenance: need winter frost protection in their first year in the British Isles

35.title: Eryngium alpinum
35.plantpollinatorstext: Research has shown it is a generalist
35.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed sown in pots in a cold frame as soon as seed is ripe
35.plantcultivation: Grow in fairly dry, well-drained soil that is poor to moderately fertile. Full sun is essential as is protection from winter wet
35.plantpests: Can get leaf and bud eelworms. May be affected by powdery mildews and root rot
35.plantmaintenance: Although you can cut back flower stems after flowering the seedheads are a very attractive feature so are usually left over winter

141.title: Erysimum 'Bowles's Mauve'
141.plantpollinatorstext:
is a bushy evergreen perennial up to 80 cm tall, derived from
a southern European plant, Erysimum cheiri. It must be a contender
Clockwise from top:
Yellow rattle
Hellebore
Love-in-a-mist
Aquilegia
110 111
for the plant with the longest flowering period, for ‘Bowles Mauve’
can flower for almost twelve months of the year, although the clusters
of purple flowers are at their most prolific in spring. It attracts
numerous short-tongued bumblebees, solitary bees and butterflies.
Erysimum grows best in a sunny, well-drained spot, and makes an
attractive pot plant for patios. It tends to be quite short-lived, but is
easily multiplied and replaced by taking cuttings in spring

64.title: Euphorbia corallioides
64.plantpropagation: Seed. Self-seeds readily in ideal growing conditions.
64.plantcultivation: Grow in fertile, humus-rich, sharply-drained soil in full sun. Does not easily tolerate other growing conditions. Usually loses most stem leaves toward the end of its life. Suitable for use in hot, dry gardens.
64.flowertype: Tiny flowers surrounded by prominent bracts.

63.title: Euphorbia 'Whistleberry Garnet'
63.plantpollinatorstext: Good for hoverflies and very small bees such as Hylaeus
63.plantpropagation: Propagate by division in spring, or by basal cuttings in spring or early summer; dip cut surfaces in charcoal or lukewarm water to prevent bleeding
63.plantcultivation: Grow in well-drained, light soil in full sun. May spread but is easy to control
63.plantpests:
May be affected by aphids
May be affected by stem and root rots in wet conditions
63.plantmaintenance: Cut back flowering shoots to ground level in late summer or autumn
63.flowertype: Small flowers held within cupped, often colourful bracts

26.title: Filipendula ulmaria
26.plantpollinatorstext:
A common perennial wild flower found in damp meadows, marshes
and ditch-banks, meadowsweet grows to about 1 m tall and produces
frothy sprays of numerous tiny cream flowers from June to
August. The flowers produce little nectar, but the pollen seems to
be very popular with bumblebees; in Scotland this is one of the
most common pollen types collected by buff-tailed bumblebees.
Meadowsweet is useful for damp and lightly shaded areas. It is easily
propagated by dividing clumps in early spring.

2.title: Genista lydia
2.planttext: A small pea flower alternative to the rampant ones like vetches, clovers, brooms, gorse.
2.plantpollinatorstext: Providing nutrient rich pollen, important for larvae for bumblebees and solitary bees
2.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed or semi-hardwood cuttings
2.plantcultivation: Grow in poor but well-drained soil in full sun
2.plantmaintenance: Pruning group 1. Will not tolerate hard pruning. New growth will not rejuvenate from old wood

6.title: Geranium × cantabrigiense 'Biokovo'
6.plantpollinatorstext: Bees, beneficial insects, butterflies​/​moths and other pollinators. Good bee plant nectar and pollen
6.plantpropagation: Propagate by division between early autumn and early spring or cut back plants after flowering in summer then divide, replant and water well
6.plantcultivation: Grow in moderately fertile, well-drained soil in full sun or partial shade, but most soils (unless waterlogged) in either sun or shade are tolerated
6.plantpests: May be damaged by vine weevil larvae, Geranium sawfly larvae, capsid bug, slugs and snails. Downy mildews and a virus are occasional problems. Powdery mildews in dry conditions may be troublesome
6.plantmaintenance: Remove flowered stems and old leaves to encourage the production of fresh leaves and flowers

92.title: Geranium macrorrhizum 'Bevan's Variety'
92.plantpollinatorstext: All Geraniums are visited by a variety of bee species.

15.title: Geranium phaeum 'Lily Lovell'
15.plantpollinatorstext: Poular with bumblebees which 'buzz pollinate' this species
15.plantpropagation: Propagate by division between early autumn and early spring or cut back plants after flowering in summer then divide. replant and water well
15.plantcultivation: Grow in moderately fertile well-drained soil in full sun, partial shade or deep shade. Most soils (unless waterlogged) in either sun or shade are tolerated
15.plantpests: May be damaged by vine weevil larvae, geranium sawfly larvae, capsid bug or slugs and snails. Downy mildew and a virus are occasional problems. Powdery mildew in very dry conditions may be troublesome
15.plantmaintenance: Remove flowered stems and old leaves to encourage the production of fresh leaves and flowers

66.title: Geranium rozanne
66.plantpollinatorstext: Top plant for solitary bees (according to Rosybees). Also good for honey bees and bumblebees, butterlfies, moths
66.plantpropagation: Propagate by division in spring or propagate by basal cuttings in early to mid spring and root with bottom heat
66.plantcultivation: Grow in any, moderately fertile soil apart from waterlogged soils. Full sun or partial shade is best but shade is tolerated
66.plantpests: Can get vine weevil, capsid bug and sawflies.May be affected by a downy mildew and powdery mildews
66.plantmaintenance: Remove flowered stems and old leaves to encourage the production of fresh leaves and flowers

7.title: Geranium sanguineum
7.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed, basal cuttings or division
7.plantcultivation: Good for rock garden or effective as groundcover
7.plantpests: May get vine weevil, capsid bug and sawflies.  May be affected by a downy mildew and powdery mildews
7.plantmaintenance: Remove flowered stems and old leaves to encourage the production of fresh leaves and flowers

97.title: Geranium sylvaticum
97.plantpollinatorstext: Occasionally visited by bumblebees, attracts butterflies

30.title: Helenium 'Moerheim Beauty'
30.plantpollinatorstext: Very popular with bees of all sizes
30.plantpropagation: Propagate by division in autumn or spring. Propagate by basal cuttings in cold frame in spring
30.plantcultivation: Grow in any fertile, moist but well-drained soil in full sun. Provide support for best results
30.plantpests: Generally pest free. May be affected by a leaf spot

95.title: Helichrysum italicum
95.planttext: Alternative to the invasive species of small yelllow composites. V. well behaved (MC)
95.plantpropagation: Propagate by rooting semi-hardwood cuttings of shrubby species in summer and overwinter in frost-free conditions
95.plantcultivation: Grow in a poor to moderately fertile, well-drained, neutral to alkaline soil in full sun. Protect from winter wet and cold dry winds
95.plantpests: Generally pest free . May be subject to powedery mildews

11.title: Helleborus foetidus
11.planttext: poisonous - wear gloves when cutting back.
11.plantpollinatorstext: early nectar source for bumblebees in Feb and March
11.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed sown in pots in a cold frame as soon as seed is ripe
11.plantcultivation: Thrives in neutral to alkaline soils that are moist, fertile and humus-rich. Partial shade is ideal but can tolerate full sun. Provide shelter from strong, cold winds. Mulch annually in autumn
11.plantpests: Hellebore aphid and snails may be a problem. May be subject to hellebore leaf spot and hellebore black death
11.plantmaintenance: Remove faded or damaged foliage as the flowers appear

84.title: Hyacinthoides non-scripta
84.planttext: Avoid the spanish bluebell, which hybidises with native species
84.plantpollinatorstext:
Those bees one might see are almost invariably queens of the longer-tongued
species such as the garden bumblebee (B. hortorum), and for these,
bluebells are probably an important source of food.' (DG)
84.flowertype: Bell-shaped or star-shaped blue, violet or white flowers

68.title: Hylotelephium spectabile
68.plantpropagation: Propagate by division in spring. Propagate by softwood cuttings of non-flowering shoots in early summer
68.plantcultivation: Grow in moderately fertile, well-drained, neutral to slightly alkaline soil in full sun. A drought-tolerant plant, attractive to wildlife
68.plantpests: Generally pest free, May be subject to fungal and bacterial crown rot and roots rots
68.plantmaintenance: Cut back after flowering to maintain shape or leave seedheads overwinter
68.flowertype: Small star-shaped flowers in flat terminal clusters

76.title: Inula magnifica 'Sonnenstrahl'
76.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in pots in a cold frame in spring or autumn. Propagate by division in spring or autumn
76.plantcultivation: Grow in a deep, fertile moist but well-drained soil in partial shade
76.plantpests: Generally pest free. May be affected by powdery mildews
76.flowertype: Daisy-like flower-heads, often with narrow ray-florets

34.title: Knautia arvensis
34.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in pots in a cold frame in spring or propagate by basal cuttings in spring
34.plantcultivation: Grow in a moderately fertile, well-drained, preferably alkaline soil in full sun. Attractive to bees
34.plantpests: May be attacked by aphids. Generally disease free
34.plantmaintenance: Old flower stems can be cut down after flowering

85.title: Lamium maculatum 'White Nancy'
85.plantpollinatorstext: All Lamiums are good for bumblebees (MC)
85.flowertype: 2-lipped, tubular flowers borne in whorls forming a short spike

62.title: Lavandula × chaytoriae 'Sawyers'
62.plantpropagation: Propagate by semi-hardwood cuttings, may not come true from seed
62.plantcultivation: Prefers a well-drained neutral to alkaline soil but tolerates acidic conditions. In heavy soil improve drainage as lavender does not tolerate waterlogging. Potash will encourage flowering but high nitrogen fertilisers and manure will result in 'floppy' plants
62.plantpests:
Leafhoppers may be a problem
Grey moulds may be a problem
62.flowertype: Small tubular flowers in dense spikes

58.title: Lavandula x intermedia ‘Grosso’
58.planttext: Needs a dry sunny situation. Narrow foliage and long-stemmed. Narrow leaves and small tubular flowers in dense spikes in summer.
58.plantpollinatorstext: The intermedia group of lavenders make large tall plants and are the most attractive to insects.
58.plantpropagation: Propagate by semi-hardwood cuttings, may not come true from seed
58.plantcultivation: Prefers a well-drained neutral to alkaline soil but tolerates acidic conditions. In heavy soil improve drainage as lavender does not tolerate waterlogging. Potash will encourage flowering but high nitrogen fertilisers and manure will result in 'floppy' plants
58.plantpests: Leafhoppers may be a problem,  Grey moulds may be a problem
58.plantorigin: Hybrids derived from wild species originally from S. Europe

59.title: Lavandula x intermedia 'Lullingstone Castle'
59.plantpollinatorstext: The intermedia group of lavenders make large tall plants and are the most attractive to insects.
59.plantcultivation: Plant in well-drained, preferably alkaline to neutral soil in sun. Tolerates acid soil. Best in a sheltered position. Will not tolerate waterlogged conditions. High nitrogen fertilisers & manure will cause the plant to flop. Semi-evergreen in colder areas
59.plantpests: Watch out for  Cuckoo spit , Rosemary leaf beetle and grey mould

155.title: Levisticum officinale
155.plantpollinatorstext:
However, the splendid
3-metre-tall flower spikes are very attractive to soldier beetles, wasps,
hoverflies and solitary bees. The soldier beetles in particular sit about
in copulating pairs, mating and feeding at the same time. They then
wander off to consume aphids in my vegetable patch, so I’m very
happy to give the lovage garden space, despite its culinary limitations.
It is best grown from seed sown in late spring.

20.title: Limonium platyphyllum
20.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in pots outdoors in spring or propagate by division in spring
20.plantcultivation: Best grown in sandy soil but will tolerate any well-drained soil in full sun; useful for dry stony sites
20.flowertype: Small flowers with tubular calyces and petals

50.title: Linaria purpurea 'Canon Went'
50.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in pots in a cold frame in early spring. Propagate by division or softwood cuttings in spring
50.plantcultivation: Grow in moderately fertile, light, well-drained soil; sandy soil is ideal. Full sun essential
50.plantpests:
May be attacked by aphids
May be affected by powdery mildews
50.plantmaintenance: After flowering, plants can be cut back to prevent self-seeding
50.plantorigin: Southern Europe, C. Italy to Sicily

117.title: Lobelia siphilitica
117.planttext: It is a N. American plant called Indian Tobacco that has large-lipped flowers that are adapted for bumblebees pollination. Needs damp soil. Unlike other Lobelias this a is a sound perennial and easy to grow in a damp soil.

71.title: Lotus hirsutus
71.planttext: A small pea flower alternative to the rampant ones like vetches, clovers, brooms, gorse
71.plantpollinatorstext: Providing nutrient rich pollen, important for larvae for bumblebees and solitary bees
71.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in spring at 15°C (59°F); soak first for 24 hours in hot water. Take semi-ripe cuttings in late summer
71.plantcultivation: Grow in well-drained soil in full sun
71.plantpests: Generally pest free and disease free
71.flowertype: Pea-like flowers that may be solitary or clustered

46.title: Lysimachia ephemerum
46.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in containers outdoors in spring. Divide in spring or autumn
46.plantcultivation: Grow in humus-rich, preferably moist but well-drained soil that does not dry out in summer, in full sun or part shade
46.plantpests:
May be damaged by slugs and snails
Generally disease free
46.plantmaintenance: Tidy after flowering and cut down dead foliage in late winter or early spring

560.title: Maianthemum stellatum
560.commonname: starry false llily of the valley

de.commonname: starry false llily of the valley

en.commonname: starry false llily of the valley

us.commonname: starry false llily of the valley

21.title: Nepeta sibirica
21.plantpropagation: Propagate by division in spring or autumn; take softwood stem-tip cuttings in early summer or semi-ripe cuttings in early autumn
21.plantcultivation: Grow in well-drained soil in full sun but will tolerate light shade
21.plantpests: May be damaged by slugs and snails and cats.   Powdery mildews can be problematic
21.plantmaintenance: Deadhead spent flowerheads and cut hard back at the end of the flowering season or in early spring

127.title: Onobrychis viciifolia
127.plantpollinatorstext: Produces Nectar and Pollen for Short and Long-tongued Bumblebees, Honeybees and Solitary Bees. This nectar is secreted exceptionally freely and is considered one of the highest yielding forage plants. This is one of the few honeys which is purely monofloral in the British Isles. The flowers of Sainfoin attract huge numbers of insects. According to studies, sainfoin can attract ten times more bees than white clover. There are many beekeepers who consider Sainfoin honey to be superior to that from any other source and when sainfoin flowers, it is so appealing to Honeybees that they will often ignore all other nectar sources to forage on it. Pollen is also gathered, it being one of the oiliest pollens available. As Sainfoin flowers in September will be making a big contribution towards bee’s winter reserves.

67.title: Origanum vulgare
67.planttext: Spreads at the roots but not invasively and makes nice winter ground cover when basal leaves become more strongly coloured. Self sown seedlings often green-leaved
67.plantpollinatorstext: Very attractive to bees and butterflies. particularly attractive to Short-tongued Bumblebees and Honeybees. It is also sought after by the common carder bee, Bombus pascuorum and many Solitary bees, for example the Blue mason bee, Osmia caerulescens. Butterflies are also attracted. (beehappy)
67.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed or by division in the autumn or spring
67.plantcultivation: Grow in a any well-drained (preferably alkaline) soil, in full sun or partial shade
67.plantpests: Can get leafhoppers. Generally disease free
67.plantmaintenance: Cut back old, flowered stems in early spring
67.flowertype: Tubular flowers in small terminal clusters

24.title: Papaver orientale 'Karine'
24.plantpropagation: Propagate by division in spring or propagate by root cuttings in late autumn to early winter
24.plantcultivation: Grow in deep, fertile, well-drained soil in full sun or partial shade. May need support
24.plantpests: Aphids may be a problem. May be subject to downy mildew and fungal wilts
24.plantmaintenance: Cut down once flowers fade and foliage looks tatty

131.title: Penstemon heterophyllus 'Heavenly Blue'
131.plantpollinatorstext: Excellent garden plant, small spreading evergreen for a dry very sunny position in poor sandy soil where it is covered in blue-mauve flowers for months. Very attractive to every kind of bee

51.title: Persicaria amplexicaulis
51.plantpropagation: Propagate by division in spring or autumn or propagate by seed in spring
51.plantcultivation: Grow in any moist soil in full sun or partial shade. Substantial mounds of foliage steadily increase in size, needing space and careful siting
51.flowertype: Small bell-shaped flowers in spikes or panicles

136.title: Phlomis fruticosa
136.plantpollinatorstext: A yellow Phlomisthat is visited by B. hortorum

133.title: Phuopsis stylosa
133.plantpollinatorstext: Vigorous ground cover plant for hot dry situation or gravel.Pink flowers occasionally attract butterflies and some bees. This plant can be over-vigorous for a small garden

83.title: Primula vulgaris
83.plantpollinatorstext: Queen common carder bumblebees, bee flies and hairy-footed flower bees' (DG)
83.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed or root basal cuttings
83.plantcultivation: Grow as biennials for bedding, in a container, in a woodland garden, rock garden or naturalised in grass. Favours a sheltered position in sun or partial shade
83.plantpests: May be attacked by aphids, vine weevil, slugs, leaf and bud eelworms, leaf-mining flies and glasshouse red spider mite.  May be subject to a leaf spot and grey moulds
83.flowertype: Salver-shaped or bell-shaped flowers, in umbels

5.title: Pulmonaria longifolia
5.plantpropagation: Propagate by division after flowering or in autumn
5.plantcultivation: Grow in humus-rich, fertile, moist but not waterlogged soil in full or partial shade
5.plantpests: Generally pest free. May be subject to powdery mildews in dry conditions
5.plantorigin: Western Europe, including Britain, France, Spain, Portugal

113.title: Rudbeckia fulgida
113.plantpollinatorstext:
A deservedly popular herbaceous perennial, Rudbeckia forms robust
clumps up to 1 m tall, bearing copious daisy-style flowers with chocolate-
brown centres surrounded by bright yellow petals. It is very
attractive to honeybees, and moderately attractive to short-tongued
bumblebees and some solitary bees. It will thrive in sun or partial
shade, is not fussy with regard to soil, and flowers from the beginning
of July through to the first frosts of October if it is dead-headed
regularly. Rudbeckia is easily propagated by dividing the rhizomatous
clumps, or it can be grown from seed sown in early spring.

22.title: Rudbeckia subtomentosa 'Henry Eilers'
22.plantcultivation: Prefers a fertile, moisture-retentive but well-drained soil in full sun. Benefits from support (see staking perennials)
22.plantpests: Generally trouble free. May be susceptible to powdery mildews

57.title: Salvia nemorosa 'Amethyst'
57.plantcultivation: Grow in light, moderately fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil. Best in full sun but can tolerate light partial shade
57.plantpests:
Generally pest free
and disease free
57.plantmaintenance: Remove flower spikes as they fade to prolong flowering
57.flowertype: 2-lipped flowers in whorls, forming simple or branched spikes

54.title: Salvia nemorosa 'Caradonna'
54.plantpropagation: Grow in light, moderately fertile, humus-rich, moist but well-drained soil. Mulch in spring. Best in full sun but can tolerate light partial shade. Drought-tolerant once established
54.plantcultivation: Propagate by division in spring and by semi-ripe cuttings in summer
54.plantpests: Generally trouble-free but may suffer from slugs, snails and leafhoppers.  Generally disease free
54.plantmaintenance: Deadhead flower spikes as they fade to prolong flowering

61.title: Salvia yangii
61.flowertype: Small tubular flowers in dense spikes

29.title: Sanguisorba officinalis
29.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in pots in a cold frame in spring or autumn. Propagate by division in spring or autumn
29.plantcultivation: Grow in a moderately fertile, moist but well-drained soil that does not dry out; best in full sun or partial shade. Usually needs support and the rhizomes can spread and become invasive so site with care

17.title: Selinum wallichianum
17.plantpollinatorstext: Beneficial insects, butterflies, moths, and other pollinators
17.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in pots in a cold frame as soon as seed is ripe; prick out into deep containers to avoid tap root damage. Propagate by division in early spring but take care as it resents disturbance
17.plantcultivation: Grow in moderately fertile, moist but well-drained soil in full sun or partial shade
17.plantpests: Slugs and snails may be a problem. May be subject to powdery mildews in dry conditions
17.plantmaintenance: Remove faded flowerheads and cut back dying foliage in autumn

3.title: Senecio cineraria
3.planttext: Alternative to the invasive species of small yelllow composites. V. well behaved (MC)
3.plantpollinatorstext: For mining bees. Leaves are food for cinnabar moth caterpillar.

102.title: Solidago virgaurea
102.plantpollinatorstext:
Goldenrods are amongst the most important wild flowers for bumblebees
in North America, but only one relatively scarce species
(Solidago virgaurea) is native to the UK. A number of garden varieties
are also available, all clump-forming perennials usually growing to
about 1 m tall, and producing very attractive arching sprays of tiny
yellow flowers in late summer and autumn. Goldenrods are attractive
to many different bees, including bumblebees, honey bees, sweat
bees and nomad bees. They can thrive in very poor soil, but prefer
an open situation. Propagation is easiest by dividing existing clumps.

53.title: Stachys byzantina
53.planttext: Make sure to get a flowering clone, many in garden centres are non-flowering forms.
53.plantpollinatorstext: Magnet for the Wood Carder Bee (Anthidium manicatum). The male bees patrol their territories and attack intruder insects. Used as a forage by bumblebees and other insects.
53.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed in containers in a cold frame in autumn or spring. Propagate by division or remove rooted sections in spring
53.plantcultivation: Grow in moderately fertile, well-drained soil in full sun
53.plantpests: Slugs and caterpillars may be a problem.  May be subject to powdery mildews
53.plantmaintenance: Remove flowers to prolong the life of the plant
53.plantorigin: Turkey, Armenia, Iran, SE Europe, naturalised in UK?

72.title: Symphyotrichum oblongifolium
72.plantpropagation: Sow seeds, 5/8 deep, outside in fall or provide cold stratification. Also propagated by softwood cuttings taken in late spring.
72.plantcultivation: Aster oblongifolius ‘Raydon’s Favorite’ grows best in full sun but will tolerate partly shaded areas that have at least a half day of sun.  If planted with aggressive taller plants, this aster will decline.
72.plantpests: No serious pest or disease issues. Keep an eye out for powdery mildew
72.plantmaintenance: Pinch back stems before midsummer to promote bushiness, produce a greater no of flowers, and control plant height.

100.title: Symphytum officinale
100.plantpollinatorstext: Comfrey is a very hardy perennial, great for the back of an herbaceous border or a forgotten corner where it will look after itself. In theory it prefers moist locations, but in my experience it doesn’t care too much. Comfrey has a very long flowering period, with a peak in late May and June, but then smaller numbers of flowers right through to October. It is a great plant for bees, visited by both longand short-tongued species, the latter often robbing from holes bitten in the tops of the flowers. Comfrey can be chopped down regularly and used to make excellent potassium-rich compost, or steeped in water to produce a foul-smelling but highly nutritive liquid compost for tomatoes. It sprouts back up vigorously after being cut back, and has a renewed flush of flowering. Comfrey can grow 1.5 m tall or more, and will smother smaller plants nearby. It propagates incredibly easily from root cuttings, and because of this is rather difficult to get rid of should you ever wish to, for even a tiny fragment of root left behind will soon form another plant.

60.title: Teucrium chamaedrys
60.planttext: grown as ground-cover in free-draining or rockery situation and tolerates or even enjoys light shade.
60.plantpropagation: Propagate by soft wood cuttings in early summer or semi ripe cuttings in mid summer. Rooted cuttings will need winter protection in a cool greenhouse or cold frame
60.plantcultivation: Grow in well-drained prefrably neutral to alkaline soil in full sun
60.plantpests:
Generally pest free
and disease free
60.plantmaintenance: Prune in spring, trim any winter damaged foliage

47.title: Teucrium hircanium
47.planttext: A useful vertical for virtually any soil or situation.

99.title: Thalictrum aquilegifolium
99.plantpollinatorstext:
Meadow rue is a vigorously growing herbaceous perennial, native
to continental Europe. It forms slowly spreading clumps up to
about 1 m in height, and produces attractive creamy-pink clusters
of fluffy-looking flowers in late spring, enjoyed by many insects
but particularly popular with hoverflies. This is a useful plant as it
favours damp, boggy areas with some shade, conditions that do not suit many pollinator-friendly plants. Propagate by splitting clumps in early spring, or by seed.

184.title: Tradescantia ‘Osprey’
184.plantdescription: ADD TO CONTINENTAL ATLANTIC EUROPE WHEN DRAWN

44.title: Verbascum nigrum
44.planttext: short lived, seeds itself, leaves prone to being eaten by colourful caterpillars of 'mullein gaer' moth
44.plantpropagation: Usually found on calcareous, free-draining sites or disturbed ground. Mulleins are beneficial to wildlife as a pollen and nectar source when in flower, seeds are a food source for birds and in winter hollow stems act as a refuge for insects
44.plantpests:
May be attacked by mullein moth
Generally disease free

148.title: Verbascum olympicum
148.planttext: A magnificent tall branching plant much used by nature-garden designers in Germany. Good winter rosette of leaves. Biennial or short-lived perennial. Get seeds on-line from Germany. V. longifolium is similar
148.plantpollinatorstext: Produces pollen only. Much visited by bumblebees and solitary bees, and has a very long season of flower.

77.title: Verbena hastata
77.plantpropagation: Propagate by seed, division or softwood cuttings
77.plantcultivation: Grow in a moist but well-drained moderately fertile soil in full sun
77.flowertype: 5-petalled, salver-shaped flowers, typically held in spikes or panicles

48.title: Veronica longifolia 'Marietta'
48.plantpropagation: Propagate by division in autumn or spring
48.plantcultivation: Grow in loamy, moderately fertile, moist but well-drained soil in full sun or partial shade
48.plantpests:
Generally pest free
May be subject to a downy mildew, powdery mildews and a leaf spot
48.plantorigin: Central and NE Europe, S.W. Asia, Mongolia, Korea, N. China
48.flowertype: tiny, tubular, flowers in dense spikes

49.title: Veronica spicata 'Glory'
49.plantcultivation: Needs full sun and grows best in a well-drained soil
49.plantpests:
Generally trouble free
May be affected by powdery mildews and downy mildew

45.title: Veronicastrum virginicum f. roseum 'Pink Glow'
45.plantcultivation: Grow in moderately fertile, humus-rich, moist soil in full sun or partial shade
45.plantpests: Generally pest free  May be subject to a downy mildew, powdery mildews and a leaf spot
45.plantmaintenance: Remove flower spikes as they fade
45.flowertype: long terminal racemes of small flowers

43.title: Veronicastrum virginicum 'Fascination'
43.plantcultivation: Grow in moderately fertile, humus-rich, moist soil in full sun or partial shade
43.plantpests:
Generally pest free
May be subject to a downy mildew, powdery mildews and a leaf spot
43.plantmaintenance: Remove flower spikes as they fade

116.title: Vicia cracca
116.plantpollinatorstext: Tufted Vetch. A very good bumblebee forage plant
